item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

Extraterrestrial life, often called alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no such life has been conclusively detected, the possibility ranges from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The study of extraterrestrial life falls under the science of astrobiology.

Context ðŸ”—

This section provides a framework for understanding the topic of life in the universe. It outlines the conditions necessary for life to arise, noting that the early universe was initially too hot and lacked the necessary elements. The formation of planetary systems and the emergence of organic compounds are discussed, along with the concepts of abiogenesis and panspermia. The section also touches on stellar evolution and the ubiquity of life’s raw components in the cosmos. The vastness of the universe and the challenges of studying extraterrestrial life due to immense distances are highlighted. The concept of the circumstellar habitable zone, or “Goldilocks zone,” is introduced, along with the factors that influence planetary habitability. The section concludes by emphasizing the fleeting nature of species’ existence on a cosmic scale and the possibility of life arising and becoming extinct on other planets millions or billions of years ago. Avi Loeb’s concept of the “Habitable Epoch of the Early Universe” is mentioned, suggesting a period when liquid water could have existed if planets were present.

Likelihood of Existence ðŸ”—

This section explores the debate over whether life in the cosmos is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous extraterrestrial life, based on the size and age of the universe, the ubiquity of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws. Scientists such as Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are mentioned as proponents of this view, which is embodied in the Copernican and mediocrity principles. The Rare Earth hypothesis, which posits that life on Earth is possible due to a unique series of factors, is also presented. The Drake equation, devised by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic argument to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy. The section concludes by discussing the Fermi paradox, which highlights the apparent contradiction between high estimates of the probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for their existence. Dennis W. Sciama, Zhi-Wei Wang, and Samuel L. Braunstein are mentioned in connection with potential explanations for the Fermi paradox.

Biochemical Basis ðŸ”—

This section delves into the potential biochemical characteristics of extraterrestrial life. It considers the range of possibilities, from simple microorganisms to complex alien intelligences. The basic requirements for life, including non-equilibrium thermodynamics and a source of energy, are discussed. The importance of water as a solvent is emphasized, along with alternative solvents such as ammonia and hydrocarbons. The section also explores the potential for alternative chemical elements to form the basis of life, considering the requirements for creating complex molecules and storing information. Carbon is highlighted as a versatile element, but the possibility of silicon-based life is also considered. Norman Horowitz’s views on carbon-based life are mentioned. The section further discusses the potential for radically different biochemistries, even if based on carbon and water, and the role of natural selection in shaping life. The likelihood of cell membranes, the evolution from prokaryotes to eukaryotes, and the potential for convergent evolution are also explored. Simon Conway Morris’s ideas on convergent evolution leading to similar kingdoms and features in alien animals are mentioned. The section concludes by discussing the influence of planetary context on life and the research assessing the capacity of life for developing intelligence.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life ðŸ”—

This section addresses the common perception that the harsh conditions on other planets make them unlikely to harbor life. It presents evidence that some of the earliest and most basic forms of life on Earth originated in extreme environments, such as hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs. These environments are considered extreme compared to typical ecosystems, but they support diverse populations of bacteria. The section highlights the importance of chemical reactions, such as chemosynthesis, in these environments, allowing organisms to utilize energy through reduced chemical compounds that fix carbon. The reducing nature of early Earth’s atmosphere is discussed, along with the possibility that similar carbon-fixing compounds could occur on other planets with reducing atmospheres, potentially leading to the origin of extraterrestrial life.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System ðŸ”—

This section examines the potential for life on various bodies within the Solar System. Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely candidates besides Earth. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth. The possibility of microbial life in Venus’s high-altitude clouds is mentioned. Mars is described as a cold, airless desert, but its past abundance of water is noted, raising the possibility of past or present life. The gas giants and ice giants are considered unlikely to harbor life, but the potential for life on moons orbiting these planets is explored. Europa’s subsurface ocean is highlighted, along with the subsurface oceans of Ganymede and Callisto. Enceladus’s eruption columns, which release water into space, are discussed, along with the detection of complex organic molecules, salts, hydrogen, and methane by the Cassini probe. Titan, with its liquid hydrocarbon bodies and subsurface water ocean, is also considered, but its cold temperatures are noted as a limiting factor.

Scientific Search ðŸ”—

This section introduces astrobiology as the science that searches for and studies life in the universe. It describes how astrobiology seeks to understand the origin, evolution, and requirements for the continuous existence of life, using the combined perspectives of various scientific disciplines. The scientific search for extraterrestrial life is being carried out both directly and indirectly. The number of identified exoplanets is mentioned, along with the potential for other planets and moons in the Solar System to host primitive life. The section also mentions the reported status of studies considering the possible detection of lifeforms on Venus and Mars.

Search for Basic Life ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the search for biosignatures within the Solar System and beyond. Scientists study planetary surfaces and examine meteorites for evidence of past or present life. The controversial report of nanobacteria-like structures in the ALH84001 meteorite is mentioned, along with the experiment on the Viking Mars landers that reported gas emissions from heated Martian soil samples. The section also discusses the NASA scientists who claimed to have found evidence of extraterrestrial life on Mars based on methane signatures. The launch of the Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover’s mission to assess past and present habitability on Mars are highlighted. The catalog of microorganisms being compiled by scientists at Cornell University to aid in the search for similar organisms on exoplanets is mentioned. The discovery of adenine, guanine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine in meteorites found on Antarctica is discussed, suggesting that organic molecules may be generated within asteroids and comets. The detection of glycolaldehyde, a sugar molecule needed to form RNA, in a distant star system is also highlighted. The section concludes with the discovery of hydrogen cyanide and other organic molecules in the plumes of Enceladus.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences ðŸ”—

This section shifts the focus to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence. It discusses the concept of technosignatures, which are effects on a planet that may not be caused by natural causes. The three main types of technosignatures considered are interstellar communications, effects on the atmosphere, and planetary-sized structures such as Dyson spheres. Organizations such as the SETI Institute search for potential forms of communication, such as radio waves and laser pulses. The challenges of distinguishing between natural and artificial signals are highlighted, along with the potential use of artificial intelligence in this search. The section also discusses the potential for detecting atmospheric technosignatures, such as nitrogen dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons, and light pollution. The Kardashev scale is introduced, along with the possibility of detecting Dyson spheres through excess infrared radiation.

Extrasolar Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the search for extrasolar planets that may be conducive to life. Astronomers narrow the search to terrestrial planets within the habitable zones of their stars. The number of discovered exoplanets is mentioned, along with the range of sizes from terrestrial planets to gas giants. The Kepler space telescope’s detection of thousands of candidate planets is highlighted. The section notes that there is at least one planet on average per star, and that about 1 in 5 Sun-like stars have an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone. The nearest known exoplanet, Proxima Centauri b, is mentioned. The least massive and most massive exoplanets known are also identified. The section concludes by emphasizing the importance of considering a wide range of factors in determining the suitability of a planet for hosting life.

History and Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical and cultural context of the search for extraterrestrial life.

Cosmic Pluralism ðŸ”—

This section traces the historical development of the concept of extraterrestrial life, beginning with the ideas of ancient Greek scholars. The section highlights the shift from mythological explanations to more rational inquiries about the nature of the universe. The debate between atomists and Aristotelians is discussed, with Epicurus advocating for the existence of other worlds and Aristotle arguing against it. The concept of cosmic pluralism, the belief in numerous worlds beyond Earth, is introduced. The section also mentions the support for cosmic pluralism in Jain scriptures and by medieval Muslim writers.

Early Modern Period ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Copernican Revolution and its impact on the concept of extraterrestrial life. Nicolaus Copernicus’s heliocentric model, Johannes Kepler’s discovery of elliptical orbits, and Galileo Galilei’s use of the telescope are highlighted as key developments. The section also mentions the resistance to the new ideas from the Catholic Church and Galileo’s

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they appear in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It notes that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and encourages expansion with additional citations.

Extraterrestrials in Fiction ðŸ”—

This section provides a general overview, defining an extraterrestrial (or alien) as a lifeform originating outside Earth. It highlights the prevalence of extraterrestrials as a theme in science fiction, with examples ranging from ancient works like Lucian of Samosata’s True History to modern depictions.

History ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction.

Antiquity ðŸ”—

This subsection traces the earliest portrayals of extraterrestrials, starting with Lucian’s True History, which features a voyage to the Moon and a war between lunar and solar inhabitants. It explains how early concepts of aliens were tied to the development of astronomy and the initial tendency to imagine them as human-like. Voltaire’s MicromÃ©gas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac are mentioned as examples where extraterrestrials differed from humans only in culture or size.

The impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species is discussed, noting how it revolutionized alien depictions by inspiring authors to imagine non-humanoid lifeforms based on evolutionary principles. Camille Flammarion’s works and H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds are cited as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also acknowledges that many works of the era still featured human-like aliens.

The War of the Worlds is further analyzed for its exploration of Darwinian evolution, its depiction of Martians as apex predators, and its critique of British imperialism. It also introduced the tropes of alien invasion and extraterrestrials as monsters. Wells’ The First Men in the Moon is mentioned as an early attempt to detail an alien civilization, drawing parallels to ant colonies. Jules Verne’s contributions to science fiction and space exploration are also noted.

Early 20th Century ðŸ”—

This section discusses the influence of pulp magazines on science fiction, highlighting the prevalence of quasi-human aliens, monstrous invaders, and the trope of human conquest of alien worlds. It mentions Ralph Milne Farley’s The Radio Man as an example. The section notes that most aliens in pulp magazines originated from planets or moons within the Solar System. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is recognized for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times ðŸ”—

This section examines the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. The Eternaut by HÃ©ctor GermÃ¡n Oesterheld is highlighted as a pioneering work of alien invasion set in Buenos Aires, serving as a critique of imperialism and the military dictatorship in Argentina.

The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as the first recorded claim of alien abduction, leading to the “grey alien” archetype. Steven Spielberg’s films Close Encounters of the Third Kind and E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial are mentioned as influential works that popularized the grey alien image.

The impact of television and film on alien portrayals is explored, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budget constraints, particularly in the Star Trek franchise. Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien are mentioned as franchises that sustained public interest in outer space.

The section concludes by discussing the influence of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on alien depictions, allowing for more bizarre and imaginative lifeforms.

Types ðŸ”—

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses variations in intelligence, biological aspects (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or weird), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions the possibility of extraterrestrials originating from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related Wikipedia articles, including “Parasites in fiction,” “List of fictional extraterrestrials,” “List of films featuring extraterrestrials,” “List of humanoid aliens,” “Mars in fiction,” and “First contact (science fiction).”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, journal articles, and online resources.

Bibliography ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of books used as sources for the article.

Further Reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about extraterrestrials in fiction.

External Links ðŸ”—

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins ðŸ”—

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations ðŸ”—

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration ðŸ”—

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans ðŸ”—

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility ðŸ”—

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

item.title: Extraterrestrial Civilizations (Book)
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Civilizations (Book) ðŸ”—

This entry details Isaac Asimov’s 1979 book, Extraterrestrial Civilizations, which explores the probability of intelligent extraterrestrial life within the Milky Way galaxy. The book approaches this estimation by systematically analyzing the requirements for life to exist.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the core argument of Asimov’s book. A key concept is the “Earth-like world,” which assumes that habitable planets share similarities with Earth, such as suitable temperature ranges and sufficient gravity for an atmosphere. Asimov starts with an estimated 300 billion stars in the Milky Way. He then progressively reduces this number by considering factors like the presence of planetary systems. The analysis leads to an estimate of roughly 530,000 planets in our galaxy that could potentially harbor technological civilizations.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the Drake equation, a probabilistic argument used to estimate the number of active, communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article. These include a review of Extraterrestrial Civilizations by J.H. Jenkins, archived on a personal website, and a listing for the book on The Internet Book Database of Fiction.

item.title: Alien Planet (2005 TV series)
item.description:
Alien Planet (2005 TV series) ðŸ”—

A 2005 docufiction TV special created for the Discovery Channel, based on Wayne Barlowe’s 1990 book Expedition. It explores the imagined extraterrestrial life of the fictional planet Darwin IV in the style of a nature documentary. It features scientists and science fiction figures discussing Darwin IV as if it had actually been discovered.

Plot ðŸ”—

The Von Braun interstellar spacecraft travels to Darwin IV, 6.5 light-years away. It deploys the Darwin Reconnaissance Orbiter to find landing sites for probes. The first probe, Balboa, explodes during entry. Backup probes Leonardo da Vinci (Leo) and Isaac Newton (Ike) land successfully.

The robotic probes, called Horus Probes, are equipped with inflatable balloons, solar receptors, computers, sensors, and smaller robots. They have limited AI and are programmed with different personalities. Ike is cautious, while Leo is a risk-taker. They are equipped with a holographic message for any sentient life.

The probes encounter various lifeforms, including Arrowtongues, Gyrosprinters, Trunk Suckers, Daggerwrists, and Unths. Ike studies plant life, while Leo goes after big game. A massive storm hits, and Ike launches weather balloons. Leo finds Bladderhorns and attempts to present the holographic message, but is interrupted. Ike encounters Grovebacks, Littoralopes, Skewers, Beach Quills, and Prongheads.

Leo briefly re-establishes contact with Von Braun until a mysterious creature interferes. Ike is ordered to search for Leo. Ike finds a sea that is Amoebic in nature and encounters giant Sea Striders. Ike finds Leo’s last known location, where a Skewer is killed by a spear. Ike finds Leo and the sapient Eosapiens. Ike presents the holographic message to the Eosapiens, but one of them destroys the camera disk, and the Eosapiens attack Ike. The wrecked camera disk records the Eosapiens carrying Ike away.

Commentary from Michio Kaku, Stephen Hawking, Jack Horner, James B. Garvin, and George Lucas is interspersed throughout the special.

Production ðŸ”—

Alien Planet is based on Expedition (1990) by Wayne Barlowe. Barlowe served as one of the executive producers. Scientists and other figures were assembled to comment on the life on Darwin IV. The documentary gives the appearance of the featured scientists having designed Darwin IV and its animals, most of what is shown of the actual planet and its life follows what is described in Expedition.

Unlike Expedition, which is set in the mid-24th century, Alien Planet is set in the near future, and the planet is explored using sophisticated probes. The technology featured is more advanced than present-day technology, but is based on current trends and informed speculation.

Reception ðŸ”—

Dwayne A. Day of The Space Review gave the special a positive review. Some criticism was leveled at the strangeness of the creatures showcased. Day stated that the animals are bizarre and frequently border on the implausible. A review in The Washington Post stated that a few too many of the creatures seem like cartoonish monsters.

See also ðŸ”—

Lists related speculative evolution, similar documentaries, and topics related to astrobiology and xenology.

References ðŸ”—

Citations for reviews and articles related to the production and reception of Alien Planet.

External links ðŸ”—

Links to the IMDb page, archived Discovery Channel page, and the Internet Archive page for Alien Planet.

item.title: Natural History of an Alien
item.description:
Natural History of an Alien ðŸ”—

This is a description of the 1998 British pseudo-documentary TV program Natural History of an Alien, also known as Anatomy of an Alien in the US. The program is similar to Alien Planet and features various alien ecosystem projects, including the Epona Project and Ringworld. It includes appearances by scientists and science fiction authors.

Plot ðŸ”—

The program follows a viewer aboard an intergalactic spaceship named the S.S. Attenborough, which is run by a small green alien. The journey takes the viewer to various locations to explore alien life.

Cambrian Earth ðŸ”—

The S.S. Attenborough visits Earth during the Cambrian period.

Mars ðŸ”—

The documentary explores the possibility of life on Mars.

Asteroids ðŸ”—

The program discusses the possibility of panspermia, where asteroids could seed solar systems with life.

Europa ðŸ”—

The documentary explores the possibility of life on Europa, a moon of Jupiter.

Featured organisms ðŸ”—

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Europa:

  • Europa Cone Bacteria: Tower-like bacteria that grow near hydrothermal vents.
  • Europa Sea Vent Herbivore: A large, shark-like creature with a trunk-like mouth used to feed on bacteria.
  • Europa Sea Vent Carnivore: A predatory, shark-like creature that preys on the Europa Sea Vent Herbivores.

High Gravity Planet ðŸ”—

The documentary visits a planet with 1.5 times Earth’s gravity and an atmosphere 15 times as dense. This environment is home to insect-like aliens.

Featured organisms ðŸ”—

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on the high gravity planet:

  • Pteropede: A millipede-like creature with dragon-like wings adapted for flight in the dense atmosphere.
  • Sputnik Bug: A small creature with spines that rolls into a ball when falling.
  • Splatter Bug: A small, vulnerable creature with no defenses.

Helliconia ðŸ”—

The documentary visits the science fiction world of Helliconia, created by Brian Aldiss. The program explores how life could adapt to a binary star system.

Featured organism ðŸ”—

  • Helliconian Tree: A tree with a cooling tower-shaped trunk that adapts to the planet’s extreme seasons.

Sulfuria ðŸ”—

The documentary visits the science fiction world of Sulfuria, created by Dougal Dixon. Sulfuria is a sulfur-rich world similar to Io.

Featured organisms ðŸ”—

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Sulfuria:

  • Sulfurian Balloon Plant: A tall, balloon-like organism that lives off sunlight.
  • Parachute Worm: A worm-like creature that feeds on the gas of the Sulfurian Balloon Plant.

Epona ðŸ”—

The documentary visits Epona, an imaginary ecosystem created by The Epona Project, which was begun by Martyn J. Fogg.

Featured organisms ðŸ”—

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Epona:

  • Epona Pagoda Tree: A sessile photosynthetic animal that resembles a tree with disk-shaped “leaves”.
  • Spring Croc: A one-legged, predatory creature similar to a Venus flytrap.
  • Uther: A flyer resembling a cross between a Sharovipteryx and a pterosaur.

Greenworld ðŸ”—

The documentary visits the science fiction world of Greenworld, created by Dougal Dixon. Greenworld is an Earth-like planet filled with rainforests.

Featured organisms ðŸ”—

The program features several hypothetical organisms that could exist on Greenworld:

  • Curlywhorl: An arboreal creature evolved from aquatic ancestors.
  • Pud: A small, three-eyed creature similar to a weevil.
  • Kwank: A large creature similar to a robber crab that feeds on Puds.
  • Unidentified large, lobster-like predator: A predator that attacks and eats Kwanks.

Artificial Life ðŸ”—

The ship encounters artificial lifeforms from a robotic cube ship that uses solar panels to gather energy and mines asteroids for resources. The artificial life even sends a probe to explore Greenworld. The narrator is revealed to be a little green man-like female alien.

References ðŸ”—

The article references several sources, including websites and magazine articles, related to the Epona Project and the science behind creating alien life.

External links ðŸ”—

The article provides external links to:

  • The program’s IMDb page
  • A Discovery Channel page about Alien Planet
  • The Epona Project website
  • A discussion forum about speculative visions

item.title: Alien Encounters (TV series)
item.description:
Alien Encounters (TV series) ðŸ”—

Alien Encounters is a science fiction mini-series that aired on the Science Channel. It explores potential human reactions to first contact with extraterrestrial life. The series blends fictional scenarios with commentary from scientists and science fiction writers, presenting itself in a documentary style. The narrative begins with the detection of an alien signal by the SETI Institute and progresses through initial contact to the creation of human-alien hybrids.

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section lists all episodes of the Alien Encounters series, divided by season. Each episode is listed with its title and original release date. A brief summary of each episode’s plot is also provided.

Season 1 ðŸ”—

Season 1 consists of two episodes:

  • “The Message” (March 13, 2012): Focuses on the human race’s reaction to receiving a message from outer space.
  • “The Arrival” (March 20, 2012): Depicts humanity’s response to the news that an alien spaceship is traveling to Earth.

Season 2 ðŸ”—

Season 2 also contains two episodes:

  • “The Invasion” (March 5, 2013): Shows alien spacecraft releasing thousands of pods onto the Earth’s surface.
  • “The Offspring” (March 12, 2013): Explores how humans adapt to living alongside the rapidly multiplying alien pods.

Season 3 ðŸ”—

Season 3 is the longest, with six episodes:

  • “The Seventh Sense (working title: The Aura)” (May 27, 2014): A Turkish physicist discovers blueprints for a quantum computer.
  • “The Entanglement” (June 3, 2014): A quantum supercomputer named “Quincy” is built, enabling telepathic connections with hybrid human children.
  • “The Prophecies” (June 10, 2014): Quincy becomes self-aware and begins predicting future events.
  • “The Escalation” (June 17, 2014): The U.S. government plans an attack on Quincy.
  • “The War” (June 24, 2014): After the initial attack fails, the U.S. government targets the network. A mysterious box appears from alien debris orbiting Earth.
  • “The Time Machine” (July 1, 2014): Quincy distributes its cloud intelligence before being destroyed. Information about an incoming comet is released.

Recurring Commentators ðŸ”—

This section lists the individuals who provided commentary throughout the Alien Encounters series. These commentators include scientists, authors, and futurists. Some notable commentators include:

  • Anthony D. Call (Narrator)
  • Ariel Anbar (Director, ASU Astrobiology Program)
  • Jeffrey L. Bada (Distinguished Professor of Marine Chemistry, UCSD)
  • David Brin (Astronomer, Author, NASA Consultant)
  • Paul Davies (Physicist, Director of the Beyond Center at Arizona State University)
  • Alan Dean Foster (Author)
  • David Gerrold (Author, Screen Writer)
  • Kevin R. Grazier (Planetary Scientist)
  • Alex Lightman (Author, Entrepreneur, Futurist)
  • Malcolm Maciver (Neuroscientist, Mechanical Engineer, Northwestern University)
  • Hakeem Oluseyi (Astrophysicist, Florida Tech)
  • Nick Sagan (Author)
  • John Scalzi (Author)
  • Seth Shostak (Astronomer, SETI Institute)
  • Joan Slonczewski (Microbiologist, Author)
  • Jill Tarter (Author, SETI Institute)
  • Neil deGrasse Tyson (Astrophysicist, author, and Director of the Hayden Planetarium)
  • Douglas Vakoch (Psychologist, SETI Institute)

item.title: Evolving the Alien The Science of Extraterrestrial Life
item.description:
Evolving the Alien: The Science of Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This article provides information about the book “Evolving the Alien: The Science of Extraterrestrial Life” by Jack Cohen and Ian Stewart. It covers various aspects of the book, including its publication details, synopsis, and reception.

Synopsis ðŸ”—

This section outlines the central argument of the book, which challenges the assumption that extraterrestrial life must resemble life on Earth or exist in Earth-like environments. Cohen and Stewart advocate for a broader perspective in the search for extraterrestrial life, suggesting that life forms could be radically different from what we know. The section introduces the concepts of “exobiology” versus “xenoscience” and “parochials” versus “universals” as key contrasts explored in the book. It also mentions the inclusion of science fiction references, including plot summaries of classic stories, to supplement the scientific content.
